issues.title: Security considerations
issues.author: gffletch
issues.body:
I'd recommend pulling out each point of the security considerations into it's own sub-section. This will make it clearer to the reader.

Also, the point that the enterprise is "leaking" authorization policy into the response to the client is something that I think should be more clearly stated. Or maybe call out that if this is a concern plan to use the "PAR" extension.

comments.author: identitymonk
comments.body:
Right on @gffletch , I thought about the same thing about PAR.

But a PAR starting at the RP would even better. Might worth discussing as a separate proposal maybe?

comments.author: identitymonk
comments.body: Solved by #4 last commit

issues.title: Adding reference to RFC 9470 OAuth 2.0 Step Up Authentication Challenge Protocol
issues.author: identitymonk
issues.body:
Feedback from @aaronpk

> Justify why a new spec and one the 403 and not a 401.
Here we expect the token to have gone through conventional OAuth2 validation first before a decision is made on the content of the claims, including the authorization_details

issues.title: Support for `method` of type `urn:ietf:params:oauth:grant-type:token-exchange`
issues.author: identitymonk
issues.body:
As partially discussed in #2 and as part of all the discussions on Agent as actor in the process of asking a step-up of the authorization, we could add from the beginning the support of the OAuth2 Token Exchange flow.

This could ease the path for https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/draft-oauth-ai-agents-on-behalf-of-user/

issues.title: Refinement of 401 and 403 responses
issues.author: yaron-zehavi

comments.author: identitymonk
comments.body:
The EKYC seems like a fair proposal, will add that to the dicussion points in IETF-123 Madrid

In the meantime, adding [ Draft-OAuth2.1 / Section5.3.2 ](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/draft-ietf-oauth-v2-1-12#section-5.3.2) has reference for :
- `403` being a valid HTTP Error Code for  Instructive response too
- `403` supporting `WWW-Authenticate` HTTP header

comments.author: yaron-zehavi
comments.body: Edited issue & responses to reflect today's discussion

comments.author: identitymonk
comments.body:
I am little bit lost as it seemed to me that:
- the agreed proposal was to have `resource_metdata_uri` as challenge of `WWW-Authenticate` with the ability to set a second or alternative challenge to `body_instructions` if a body was present
- `informative` and `instructive` should no longer be specified anymore as it is to the client to decide along which flow to execute the response
- in fact saying:

```
{
  "loc": "/gty",
  "method": "simple",
  "values": ["authorization_code_flow", "client_credentials"]
}
```
is already bearing the sense that the claim gty is expected. There is no need to encpsulate it in a `"expected_claims"` nor an `Informative` clause.

- we agreed that `authorization_detaills` would then be represented as:

```
{
  "loc": "/authorization_details",
  "method": "simple",
  "value": {
	"type": "payment_initiation",
		"actions": [
			"initiate",
			"status",
			"cancel"
		],
		"locations": ["https://example.com/payments"],
		"instructedAmount": {
			"currency": "EUR",
			"amount": "123.50"
		},
		"creditorName": "Merchant A",
		"creditorAccount": {
			"iban": "DE02100100109307118603"
		},
		"remittanceInformationUnstructured": "Ref Number Merchant"
	}
 }
```

without any notion of `instructive` as the client will decide how to proceed, if pby RAR, PAR, JAR or any other mean it sees fit.

comments.author: identitymonk
identitymonk
comments.body:
Finally ASC does not allow OneOf or Among comparisons. 

1. What if I want to say that `scope` must be one of ['A', 'B'] ?
2. What if I want to say that `scope` must contain 'A' and 'B' without necessarily be `A B`? meaning that `A B C` and `A D B` should be valid too.

comments.author: yaron-zehavi
comments.body:
Thanks @identitymonk agree with comments. I made the change at night before going to bed and already had thoughts in the same direction as you. I've reworked it using your proposal.

ASC supports oneOf. See:
https://openid.bitbucket.io/ekyc/openid-connect-advanced-syntax-for-claims.html#name-syntax-and-processing

"For values, the claim value must exactly match at least **one of** the values in the array"

However, ASC does not support 2Of, as in `scope` must contain 'A' and 'B'. I think when considering `scope` that's okay as also API GW's process it as oneOf. If it's a gap we can discuss it with Daniel Fett to enhance his draft

issues.title: Dicuss ability for RP to return a reference to Request Object as defined in section 2.2 of JWT-Secured Authorization Request [RFC9101]
issues.author: identitymonk
issues.body:
While it is possible for the RP to return a Request Object as defined in section 2.2 of JWT-Secured Authorization Request [RFC9101] signed by the RP for the client to send to the AS, as of now there is no standard for an RP to push a JAR to the AS using Pushed Authorization Request and pass the reference URI to the client.

The group need to discuss more this proposition.

comments.author: yaron-zehavi
comments.body: I'm a bit confused, RP == client right? So maybe you meant RS where RP appears?

comments.author: identitymonk
comments.body: RP === Resource Provider === Resource Server and not the Client

comments.author: yaron-zehavi
comments.body: I see, RP is also an OpenID term for Relying Party, which confused me

issues.title: Feedback to -01 version
issues.author: yaron-zehavi
issues.body:
- Introduction still mentions 2 error codes: "with a new error codes, `failed_authorization` and `insufficient_authorization`"
- 4.1 "The resource server responds with a 403 HTTP status code using the Bearer authentication scheme's error parameter". Maybe not critical for now, but we should consider DPoP tokens as well, where `Bearer` doesn't fit
- Typo in 5 https://www.ietf.org/archive/id/draft-lombardo-oauth-step-up-authz-challenge-proto-01.html#name-client-action-following-a-s, Should read "Step-Up" where "Setp-Up" is written
- 6 Authorization Response https://www.ietf.org/archive/id/draft-lombardo-oauth-step-up-authz-challenge-proto-01.html#name-authorization-response - Perhaps can be removed as it doesn't change anything in how AS works
- Same for 7 https://www.ietf.org/archive/id/draft-lombardo-oauth-step-up-authz-challenge-proto-01.html#name-information-conveyed-via-th

comments.author: identitymonk
comments.body:
thanks @yaron-zehavi.

All taken into account.  One comment on:

>4.1 "The resource server responds with a 403 HTTP status code using the Bearer authentication scheme's error parameter". Maybe not critical for now, but we should consider DPoP tokens as well, where Bearer doesn't fit

DPoP is proof  that the token issued is played by the client it has been issued to. Here the step-up Authorization signal is not commenting on DPoP but on the content of the access token presented as bearer token (whatever along a DPoP token or not. So the scheme is the right one as the challenge is concerning the Access Token. Up to the client to present a new Bearer Access Token based on this information with or without a DPoP token.

Still I think that the notion of the DPoP token verification is an interesting ask in the scope of AuthZEN (@baboulebou )

comments.author: identitymonk
comments.body:
Update following team call:

- Updated Authors list
- Created acknowledgement
- Added reference to RFC9470
- Added references and examples for FAPI 2.0 Security Profiles as long SMART on FHIR
- Corrected AuthZEN payload in response
- Changed Applicative Error Code based on decisions (did not not change 403 for 401)
- Changed Applicative Error description
- Modified JAR parameter and removed Request parameter
- Removed AS metadata requirements
- Reworked Security Section
We need to check why this is a change
I ponder if we should not rename `insufficient_delegated_authorization` as `insufficient_authorization` to simplify as the other error code
oxford comma

- `the methods by which`
- We might need to rework the sentence `this document rather describes the methoids by which the resource provider can signal to the client the type(s) of authorization garantees it is expected to obtain from the authorization server for the given request.`
The Request does not have an internal authorization state requirements. It is fixed by the RP with the help of a PDP (optionally) so it is really `the` and not `its`
We should have a complete see section X - below is too vague in guidance
see comment on simplify this error code
Should we not replace the `SHOULD` here with a `SHALL`
As we removed the diagram with `<payload>` we can switch to the formal `HTTP body payload` mention here
We need to do a pass on all MUST / SHOULD and other RFC keywords for the usage for of uppercase representation
As we have the AuthZEN example after this one, maybe we can remove this one
We should ensure this message for this error code is also AuthZEN formatted
While markdown resolves the numbering properly, it might not be the case of other RFC format - we need to solve that here
I agree !
Done, check for new commit.
"its" refers to the "Resource Server" coming right after the ",". I reworked the sentence, should be clearer now.
Done.
done
Well I think it helps clarify things, may be redundant but not quite. It should an actual AuthZEN response (from the authzen spec), wanted to show an actual example.
done

pulls.title: Jeff review 0626
pulls.author: identitymonk
pulls.body:
This PR is taking into account all the discussions of the meeting of June 26th as long as the follow-up discussions with Yaron:

- numbering
- formatting of http code
- merging of error code
- removal of JAR
- formatting of WWW-Authenticate
- Formating of AuthZEN response with ASC taxonomy
- Adding of OAuth2 Protected Resource capability
